article.title: A ${\bf 1.4}$ deg${\bf ^2}$ blind survey for CII], CIII] and CIV at ${\bf z∼0.7-1.5}$. I: nature, morphologies and equivalent widths

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the grey shaded area in Figure 1 represent?
choices: The redshift range where the NB filter is sensitive to [OII], [NeV], MgI and MgII.
The redshift range where the NB filter is sensitive to Lya.
The redshift range where the NB filter is sensitive to CII], CIII] and CIV.
The redshift range where the NB filter is not sensitive to any emission lines.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the purpose of the narrow photometric redshift ranges chosen for selecting CII], CIII], and CIV emitters?
choices: To ensure a high detection rate of faint, high-redshift sources.
To minimize contamination from bright, low-redshift emitters.
To maximize the number of sources with both photometric and spectroscopic redshifts.
To prioritize sources with strong Lyman-alpha emission.

multiple_choice_question.text: According to Figure 3, which type of emitter exhibits colours that are atypical for their redshift, lying in a region more typical of higher-redshift star-forming galaxies?
choices: CII] emitters
CIII] emitters
CIV emitters
Both A and C

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 7 shows the rest-frame equivalent width (EW) distribution for highly secure CII], CIII], and CIV emitters. What is a possible explanation for the presence of a significant population of all three emitter types with large rest-frame EWs, extending up to 200 Å?
choices: The NB observations used to measure the EWs are not accurate compared to spectroscopic observations.
All of these high EW sources are contaminated by Lya emitters at higher redshifts.
Offsets between the main line emission region and the location of the bulk stellar light.
The sample is dominated by highly variable AGN, mimicking a color excess and leading to overestimated EWs.

multiple_choice_question.text: Based on the data presented in Table 5, which emitter type shows the highest average black hole accretion rate (BHAR), consistent with strong AGN activity?
choices: CII] emitters
CIII] emitters
CIV emitters
All emitter types show similar BHAR values.
